member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.BooleanToVisibilityConverter
member.summary: An implementation of that converts boolean values to values.

remarks.para: The BooleanToVisibilityConverter class can be used to convert boolean values (or values that can be converted to boolean values) to values. By default, is converted to and is converted to . However, the property can be set to in order to return instead of . In addition, the property can be set to to reverse the returned values.

member.example:
The following example shows how a BooleanToVisibilityConverter can be used to display a TextBox only when a property is true:
<TextBox Visibility="{Binding ShowTheTextBox, Converter={BooleanToVisibilityConverter}}"/>

The following example shows how a BooleanToVisibilityConverter can be used to display a TextBox only when a property is true. Rather than collapsing the TextBox, it is hidden:
<TextBox Visibility="{Binding ShowTheTextBox, Converter={BooleanToVisibilityConverter UseHidden=true}}"/>

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.CaseConverter
member.summary: An implementation of that converts the casing of the input string.

remarks.para: The CaseConverter class can be used to convert input strings into upper or lower case according to the property. Setting is a shortcut for setting both and . It is therefore possible to specify that the source and target properties be converted to different casings.

member.example:
The following example shows how a CaseConverter can be used to convert a bound value to upper-case:
<Label Content="{Binding Name, Converter={CaseConverter Upper}}"/>

The following example shows how a CaseConverter can be used to convert a bound value to upper-case, but display it in lower-case:
<Label Content="{Binding Name, Converter={CaseConverter SourceCasing=Upper, TargetCasing=Lower}}"/>

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.ConverterGroup
member.summary: An implementation of that allows multiple implementations to be grouped together and executed in a pipeline.

remarks.para: The ConverterGroup class allows multiple implementations to be executed in a pipeline in order to perform a conversion. The method executes the method on each converter in the collection. The method executes the method on each converter in reverse order.

member.example:
The following example shows how a can be converted to local time prior to being formatted for display:
<Label> <Label.Content> <Binding Path="StartDateTime"> <Binding.Converter> <ConverterGroup> <DateTimeConverter TargetKind="Local"/> <FormatConverter FormatString="{0:t}"/> </ConverterGroup> </Binding.Converter> </Binding> </Label.Content> </Label>

The following example shows a ConverterGroup being used to convert user input to either or . If the user types "Yes" in the TextBox then the CheckBox will be checked. If the user types "No" then the TextBox will be unchecked. Any other value will result in the CheckBox being in an indeterminate state. Note that the comparisons are case-insensitive thanks to the .
<TextBox x:Name="_textBox"/> <CheckBox IsThreeState="True"> <CheckBox.IsChecked> <Binding Path="Text" ElementName="_textBox" FallbackValue="{x:Null}"> <Binding.Converter> <ConverterGroup> <CaseConverter Casing="Upper"/> <MapConverter> <Mapping From="YES"> <Mapping.To> <sys:Boolean>True</sys:Boolean> </Mapping.To> </Mapping> <Mapping From="NO"> <Mapping.To> <sys:Boolean>False</sys:Boolean> </Mapping.To> </Mapping> </MapConverter> </ConverterGroup> </Binding.Converter> </Binding> </CheckBox.IsChecked> </CheckBox>

member.summary: The or methods are called as necessary. The 's value is adjusted accordingly.

member.summary: The method is used to change the kind of the without affecting its value.

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.DateTimeConverter
member.summary: An implementation of that converts s between specified s.

remarks.para: The DateTimeConverter can be used to convert s between different s as required by the source and target of a data binding. The specifies the that the source stores the in, whilst the specifies the that the target stores the in.
If is assigned to either or then no conversion will take place in that direction.

member.example:
The following example shows how a DateTimeConverter can be used to convert a UTC date to local time:
<Label Content="{Binding StartDateTime, Converter={DateTimeConverter TargetKind=Local}}"/>

The following example shows how a DateTimeConverter can be used to adjust a DateTime by 3 minutes:
<Label Content="{Binding StartDateTime, Converter={DateTimeConverter TargetAdjustment=0:3}}"/>

The following example shows how a DateTimeConverter can be used to convert DateTimes to local time for the user, but convert them back to UTC time before storing them in the bound object:
<DatePicker Value="{Binding StartDateTime, Converter={DateTimeConverter SourceKind=Utc, TargetKind=Local}}"/>

The following example shows how a DateTimeConverter can be used to convert DateTimes to local time without adjusting the underlying value of the DateTime:
<Label Content="{Binding StartDateTime, Converter={DateTimeConverter TargetKind=Local, ConversionMode=SpecifyKindOnly}}"/>

member.summary: Gets or sets the source kind for converted s.

remarks.para: This property specifies what type of is required for the binding source. Any s converted before being applied to the source will be converted to the kind specified by this property.

member.name: P:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.DateTimeConverter.TargetKind
member.summary: Gets or sets the target kind for converted s.

remarks.para: This property specifies what type of is required for the binding target. Any s converted before being applied to the target will be converted to the kind specified by this property.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value by which the source will be adjusted during conversions.

remarks.para: This property can be used to ensure that any heading to the source of the binding will be adjusted according to the specified .

member.summary: Gets or sets a value by which the target will be adjusted during conversions.

remarks.para: This property can be used to ensure that any heading to the target of the binding will be adjusted according to the specified .

member.name: P:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.DateTimeConverter.ConversionMode
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating how s are converted between the and .

remarks.para: This property can be used to indicate how s should be converted between different s. If set to (the default), the 's value will be adjusted during conversion. If set to , the value of the is not adjusted during the conversion.

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.ExpressionConverter
member.summary: An implementation of and that converts bound values by using a C#-like expression.

remarks.para: The expression can be any valid C# expression as long as it uses only the operators discussed below. Bound values can be accessed within the expression by using curly brackets. For example, an expression of {0} will simply yield the first bound value unchanged, whereas an expression of {0} * 2 will return the value doubled.

The operators supported are listed below along with example usage. They are listed in decreasing order of precedence.
Operator Category Operator Example
Unary + +4
- -4
! !true
~ ~21
(T) (long) 3
true {0} == true
false {0} == false
Multiplicative * 4 * {0}
/ {0} / 4
% {0} % 4
Additive + {0} + 4
- {0} - 4
Shift << {0} << 4
>> {0} >> 4
Relational < {0} < 50
> {0} > 50
<= {0} <= 50
>= {0} >= 50
Equality == {0} == 50
!= {0} != 50
Logical AND & {0} & 16
Logical OR | {0} | 16
Logical XOR ^ {0} ^ 16
Conditional AND && {0} && {1}
Conditional OR || {0} || {1}
Ternary Conditional ?: {0} ? "yes" : "no"
Null Coalescing ?? {0} ?? {1} ?? "default"

member.example:
The following example shows how to use an expression converter to display the value of a slider multiplied by 2. Note that the expression must be escaped with "{}" because it includes the '{' and '}' characters. The expression on its own is "{0} * 2".
<StackPanel> <Slider x:Name="_slider"/> <Label Content="{Binding Value, ElementName=_slider}"/> <Label Content="{Binding Value, ElementName=_slider, Converter={ExpressionConverter {}{0} * 2}}"/> </StackPanel>

The following example shows how to position a Popup exactly in the center of a hosting panel. A is used to perform a calculation on the widths and heights of the containing panel and the popup itself.
<StackPanel x:Name="_panel"> <Popup IsOpen="True" Placement="Relative" PlacementTarget="{Binding ElementName=_panel}"> <Popup.HorizontalOffset> <MultiBinding Converter="{ExpressionConverter {}{0} / 2 - {1} / 2}"> <Binding Path="ActualWidth" ElementName="_panel"/> <Binding Path="ActualWidth" ElementName="_border"/> </MultiBinding> </Popup.HorizontalOffset> <Popup.VerticalOffset> <MultiBinding Converter="{ExpressionConverter {}{0} / 2 - {1} / 2}"> <Binding Path="ActualHeight" ElementName="_panel"/> <Binding Path="ActualHeight" ElementName="_border"/> </MultiBinding> </Popup.VerticalOffset>
<Border x:Name="_border" Background="White" BorderThickness="1"> <Label>Here is the popup.</Label> </Border> </Popup> </StackPanel>

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.FormatConverter
member.summary: An implementation of and that formats any bound data with a specified .

remarks.para: The FormatConverter class can be used to format bound data according to standard .NET formatting rules. It implements both the and interfaces, thus enabling usage in both Bindings and MultiBindings.
Note that this converter does not support conversions back for its implementation. Any attempt to convert multiple values back will return .

member.example:
The following example shows how a FormatConverter can be used to format a single value:
<Label Content="{Binding Name, Converter={FormatConverter {}Your name is '{0}'.}}"/>

The following example shows how a FormatConverter can be used to format multiple values:
<Label> <Label.Content> <MultiBinding Converter="{FormatConverter {}Your name is '{0}' and you were born on {1:dd/MM/yyyy}.}"> <Binding Path="Name"/> <Binding Path="Dob"/> </MultiBinding> </Label.Content> </Label>

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.MapConverter
member.summary: An implementation of that converts from one set of values to another based on the contents of the collection.

remarks.para: The MapConverter converts from one set of values to another. The source and destination values are stored in instances of inside the collection.
If this converter is asked to convert a value for which it has no knowledge, it will use the to determine how to deal with the situation.

member.example:
The following example shows a MapConverter being used to control the visibility of a Label based on a CheckBox:
<CheckBox x:Name="_checkBox"/> <Label Content="Here is the label."> <Label.Visibility> <Binding Path="IsChecked" ElementName="_checkBox" FallbackValue="Collapsed"> <Binding.Converter> <MapConverter> <Mapping To="{x:Static Visibility.Visible}"> <Mapping.From> <sys:Boolean>True</sys:Boolean> </Mapping.From> </Mapping> </MapConverter> </Binding.Converter> </Binding> </Label.Visibility> </Label>

The following example shows how a MapConverter can be used to convert between values of the enumeration and human-readable strings. Notice how not all possible values are present in the mappings. The fallback behavior is set to ReturnOriginalValue to ensure that any conversion failures result in the original value being returned:
<Label> <Label.Content> <Binding Path="UriFormat"> <Binding.Converter> <MapConverter FallbackBehavior="ReturnOriginalValue"> <Mapping From="{x:Static sys:UriFormat.SafeUnescaped}" To="Safe unescaped"/> <Mapping From="{x:Static sys:UriFormat.UriEscaped}" To="URI escaped"/> </MapConverter> </Binding.Converter> </Binding> </Label.Content> </Label>

member.name: P:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.MapConverter.FallbackBehavior
member.summary: Gets or sets the fallback behavior for this MapConverter.

remarks.para: The fallback behavior determines how this MapConverter treats failed conversions. ReturnUnsetValue (the default) specifies that any failed conversions should return , which can be used in combination with Binding.FallbackValue to default bindings to a specific value.

Alternatively, FallbackBehavior.ReturnOriginalValue can be specified so that failed conversions result in the original value being returned. This is useful where mappings are only necessary for a subset of the total possible values. Mappings can be specified where necessary and other values can be returned as is by the MapConverter by setting the fallback behavior to ReturnOriginalValue.

member.name: P:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.MapConverter.FallbackValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the value that will be returned if is set to and no mapping is present for the converted value.

member.name: P:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.MapConverter.Mappings
member.summary: Gets the collection of s configured for this MapConverter.

remarks.para: Each defines a relationship between a source object (see ) and a destination (see ). The MapConverter uses these mappings whilst attempting to convert values.

<Label Content="{Binding Value, Converter={ExpressionConverter {} {0} * 2}}"/>

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.Markup.FormatConverterExtension
member.summary: Implements a markup extension that allows instances of to be easily created.
member.remarks: This markup extension allows instance of to be easily created inline in a XAML binding. See the example below.
member.example:
The following shows how to use the FormatConverterExtension inside a binding to format values:
<Label Content="{Binding Name, Converter={FormatConverter {}Your name is '{0}'}}"/>

member.name: T:Kent.Boogaart.Converters.TypeConverter
member.summary: An implementation of that attempts to convert values between specified s.

remarks.para: The TypeConverter class can be used to attempt to convert values between a and . The method will attempt to convert values to the , whilst the method will attempt to convert values to the .

This class attempts to convert values by way of the interface. However, if the value being converted does not implement , an attempt is made to convert via a suitable . Failing that, is returned by conversion attempts.
Since the WPF binding infrastructure already performs automatic conversions, this converter is useful mainly in group scenarios when using the or classes.

member.example:
The following example shows how a TypeConverter can be used to convert integer values in the source to strings:
<TextBox Text="{Binding Age, Converter={TypeConverter SourceType=sys:Int32, TargetType=sys:String}}"/>

member.param: The value to convert.
